channel.title: NYT > Most Recent Headlines

item.title: Acabo de regresar de China. Estados Unidos no está ganando
item.description: Si Estados Unidos quiere ser competitivo frente a China, tiene que poner orden en su economía.
item.dc:creator: Steven Rattner

item.title: Word of the Day: monarch
item.description: This word has appeared in 180 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Late Night Mines Trump’s Million Mentions in the Epstein Files
item.description: “A million times? There’s not even that many references to Hamlet in the play ‘Hamlet,’” Jordan Klepper said on “The Daily Show.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Una hazaña olímpica: ver a una superestrella de k-pop en Milán
item.description: En los Juegos Olímpicos de Invierno abundan los famosos. Para los fans de Sunghoon, del grupo coreano Enhypen, llegar a ver a su ídolo en Milán es toda una prueba de resistencia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh

media:content.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Desde la semana pasada, un flujo constante de fans se ha reunido en el exterior de un hotel de Milán para ver a Sunghoon, una estrella de k-pop que está de visita con motivo de los Juegos Olímpicos.

item.title: Timothée Chalamet, Teyana Taylor and Jacob Elordi at the Oscar Nominees Luncheon
item.description: At the Oscar nominees’ luncheon, Timothée Chalamet, Teyana Taylor and Jacob Elordi mingled with documentarians and behind-the-scenes professionals.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan, Sinna Nasseri and Sela Shiloni
item.category: Come See Me in the Good Light (Movie)

media:content.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: When Perfidia met Frankenstein’s monster: Teyana Taylor and Jacob Elordi.

item.title: New York City Turned 400 Years Old. What Comes Next?
item.description: A Times project commemorated centuries of history not by looking into the past, but by exploring the city’s future.
item.dc:creator: Stefano Montali

media:content.media:credit: Sasha Arutyunova for The New York Times

item.title: Top Border Official Praised Agent Who Shot Chicago Woman, Evidence Shows
item.description: A Border Patrol agent shot Marimar Martinez five times, claiming that she tried to run him over. Newly released videos and text messages reveal fresh details about what happened.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz

media:content.media:credit: U.S. Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Illinois
media:content.media:description: Body camera footage from the shooting of Marimar Martinez in Chicago in October.

item.title: The Bangladesh Elections Are on Thursday. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Bangladesh is holding national elections for the first time since 2024, when a student movement ousted the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Saif Hasnat

media:content.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Dhaka, the capitol of Bangladesh is preparing to hold elections on Thursday.

item.title: Rusia podría tomar ciudades clave de Ucrania
item.description: Las tropas rusas han avanzado a un ritmo glacial en los últimos meses, pero los avances en el sur y el este de Ucrania podrían dar a Moscú una ventaja en las conversaciones de paz mediadas por EE. UU.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies

media:content.media:description: Una familia se preparó para evacuar su hogar en Rivne, un pueblo cercano a Guliaipolé, en el sureste de Ucrania, en enero.

item.title: Hamás conservaría algunas armas en Gaza, según una propuesta
item.description: Es poco probable que Israel retire sus soldados del enclave antes de que Hamás y otros grupos militantes depongan las armas.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Natan Odenheimer and Abu Bakr Bashir

media:content.media:credit: Saher Alghorra para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Militantes armados de Hamás buscaban el cadáver de un rehén israelí cerca de la ciudad de Gaza en noviembre.

item.title: Man Accused of Killing His Father Said He Was on a ‘Mission From God’
item.description: In a courtroom in Ireland, prosecutors detailed the rambling, manic confessions of Henry McGowan, the New York man charged with murdering his father in a luxury hotel.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins

media:content.media:credit: Brian Lawless/PA Images via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Henry McGowan of New York City is on trial in Ireland, accused of murder in the death of his father.

item.title: Away From Pomp of Olympics, Homeless Shiver on Streets of Milan
item.description: Six homeless people have died in the Italian city in recent weeks, highlighting the widening inequality as the Games unfold there.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Josephine de La Bruyère

media:content.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Volunteers helping a homeless person at the Garibaldi station in Milan on Sunday.

item.title: Trump Wants to Revive Shipping. Investors Are Slow to Back Him.
item.description: A French logistics behemoth promised $20 billion for the United States, but a year into President Trump’s second term, only a fraction of the money has arrived.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis

media:content.media:credit: Maansi Srivastava for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: “He’s going to be investing $20 billion into the United States because of the election,” President Trump said last year when Rodolphe Saadé, the chief executive of the shipping company CMA CGM, visited the White House.

item.title: Corrections: Feb. 11, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Feb. 11, 2026.

item.title: Quote of the Day: D.H.S. Claims In 4 Shootings Fizzle in Court
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 11, 2026.

item.title: Hong Kong Activist Anna Kwok’s Father Convicted of National Security Crime
item.description: In her first interview about her father, the exiled Hong Kong activist Anna Kwok said the authorities were targeting her family to try to silence her.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

media:content.media:description: Anna Kwok testifying during a hearing on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C., in 2023.

item.title: A Peaceful Mountain Town in Western Canada Is Shaken by Deadly Shooting
item.description: Tumbler Ridge sits at the foothills of the Rocky Mountains in northeastern British Columbia, and is surrounded by expansive mountain ranges and a geological park.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Yan Zhuang

item.title: California Man Sentenced to 4 Years for Covert Work on China’s Behalf
item.description: The man, Mike Sun, corresponded with Chinese government officials, monitored the visit of Taiwan’s president to California and backed the election of a city council member, according to court documents.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel

media:content.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Tsai Ing-wen, who was then the president of Taiwan, came to California in 2023. During her visit, she met with Kevin McCarthy, a California Republican who was the speaker of the House at that time.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Feb. 11, 2026
item.description: If you can’t take the heat, get out of Joseph Gangi’s crossword.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Live Updates: 9 Killed and 25 Injured in Shooting at School and Home in Canada
item.description: The shooting occurred in Tumbler Ridge, a remote community in British Columbia. The police said the suspected shooter died of a self-inflicted injury.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Vance Deletes Post Recognizing Armenian Genocide
item.description: President Trump has not recognized the Armenian genocide. The vice president’s office called the post an error.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater

media:content.media:description: Vice President JD Vance and the second lady, Usha Vance, visited the Tsitsernakaberd Memorial Complex in Yerevan, Armenia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Highlights From Ilia Malinin’s Short Program
item.description: With the nervousness of a first-time Olympian behind him, figure skater Ilia Malinin delivered his best routine of the Milan-Cortina Games on Tuesday, bouncing back from two relatively shaky performances in the team event to finish first in the short program with an unforgettable flourish.
item.dc:creator: Alice Fang, Jon Huang, Eden Weingart, Dan Powell and Elisheba Ittoop

item.title: 9 Killed and 25 Injured in Shootings at School and Home in British Columbia
item.description: Police say the suspected shooter died of a self-inflicted injury after the shooting in Tumbler Ridge, a remote community.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado

item.title: Elon Musk Wants to Build an A.I. Satellite Factory on the Moon
item.description: In a meeting with employees at his company xAI, Mr. Musk revealed a vision for a facility that includes a giant catapult to launch his satellites into space.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Ryan Mac

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk told employees of xAI that he plans to put a factory on the moon as a steppingstone to colonizing Mars.

item.title: N.Y.P.D. Officer Is Charged With Assault and Misconduct Over 2 Episodes
item.description: Police Officer Quran McPhatter slapped a handcuffed prisoner and threatened a man who complained about the officer’s driving, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan

item.title: Guatemala to End Use of Cuban Doctors, Under U.S. Pressure
item.description: The program, nearly 30 years old, had allowed Cuban medical workers to fill critical needs in Guatemala, while reaping income for Cuba.
item.dc:creator: Jody García and James Wagner

media:content.media:description: A Cuban doctor and a patient in San Mateo, Guatemala, in 2009. Cuba’s medical brigade of health care workers has been a fixture in Guatemala for nearly 30 years.

item.title: Prosecutors Fail to Bring Charges Against Democrats Involved in Illegal Orders Video
item.description: The rejection was a remarkable rebuke, suggesting that ordinary citizens did not believe that the lawmakers had committed any crimes.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush and Michael S. Schmidt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona and the other five Democratic lawmakers had posted a video that enraged President Trump by reminding active-duty members of the military and intelligence community of their obligation to refuse illegal orders.

item.title: México afirma que la munición incautada a cárteles procede de una planta del ejército de EE. UU.
item.description: Desde octubre de 2024, las autoridades mexicanas habían incautado 18.000 armas de fuego, de las cuales casi el 80 por ciento procedían de Estados Unidos.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega

media:content.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Un agente de policía en Villa Unión, México, con un cartucho de calibre .50. El secretario de Defensa de México dijo que se habían incautado unos 137.000 cartuchos de calibre .50 desde 2012.

item.title: Ilia Malinin’s Jumps Put Him on Top After Men’s Ice Skating Short Program
item.description: The 21-year-old American figure skater clinched the top spot in the short program by earning high scores for his jumps.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Cai, Weiyi Cai, Lazaro Gamio, Juliet Macur, Ashley Wu and Joe Ward

item.title: Mehmet Oz hace un enérgico llamado a vacunarse ante el avance del sarampión
item.description: Los comentarios del director de los Centros de Servicios de Medicare y Medicaid se producen mientras EE. UU. lucha por contener el virus, que infectó a miles de personas en 2025.
item.dc:creator: Teddy Rosenbluth
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

item.title: Trump dijo que ‘todos sabían’ de las acciones de Epstein, según un exjefe de policía
item.description: Michael Reiter, exjefe de policía de Palm Beach, relató al FBI una conversación que tuvo con Donald Trump en 2006, de acuerdo con un documento recién divulgado.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater

media:content.media:description: El relato del exjefe de policía pone de relieve las declaraciones inconsistentes que el presidente Trump ha hecho a lo largo de los años sobre su relación tanto con Jeffrey Epstein como con Ghislaine Maxwell.

item.title: ‘No Reason He Should Have Died’: Alex Pretti’s Parents Open Up
item.description: In their first sit-down interview, Michael and Susan Pretti avoided recriminations and recalled the son that Michael called “an exceptionally kind, caring man.”
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy

media:content.media:description: “The truth is, he was an exceptionally kind, caring man,” Michael Pretti said of his son, Alex.

item.title: Why the Guthrie Doorbell Footage Took More Than a Week to Retrieve
item.description: Video from a camera sold by Google probably sat in one of its vast data centers. Nancy Guthrie did not have a subscription that would have allowed easy access.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin

media:content.media:description: Images provided by the F.B.I. show surveillance footage taken at the home of Nancy Guthrie on a Nest camera.

item.title: Baboon Sibling Rivalry Suggests Monkeys Feel Jealousy Like People
item.description: Young primates in a southern African nature park were observed to constantly interfere when their mother was giving attention to a younger brother or sister.
item.dc:creator: Annie Roth
item.category: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)

item.title: George Saunders on Why the Right Is ‘on Autopilot’
item.description: The writer George Saunders is deeply attuned to the contradictions in people. On “The Ezra Klein Show,” he speculates about why many Trump supporters accept the incoherence that often exists between the president’s messaging and his administration’s actions.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: What Doorbell Camera Video of the Nancy Guthrie Kidnapping Suspect Shows
item.description: The footage provided the first glimpse of a suspect in the kidnapping of Nancy Guthrie, the mother of the television host Savannah Guthrie who has been missing for 10 days.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

item.title: Man Is Charged in 2021 Acid Attack Against Woman on Long Island
item.description: Terrell Campbell, 29, was charged with assaulting Nafiah Ikram outside her home. Mr. Campbell later described the assault in a rap lyric, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Samantha Latson

media:content.media:credit: Sara Naomi Lewkowicz for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: After the attack, Nafiah Ikram was treated for second- and third-degree burns to her face, arms, eye and esophagus.

item.title: Pentagon to Send 200 Troops to Nigeria
item.description: The troops will help train Nigerians to fight militants, but will not be involved in combat. U.S. forces have been assisting local soldiers with identifying potential terrorist targets.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: The U.S. troops will be assigned to locations across Nigeria to provide training and technical expertise, a U.S. official said.

item.title: Immigration Officials Refuse to Discuss Minnesota Shootings
item.description: During a House congressional hearing, top immigration officials repeatedly declined to answer questions about the fatal shootings of two U.S. citizens in Minnesota by federal agents.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Silva

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: From left, Rodney Scott, the commissioner of Customs and Border Protection; Joseph Edlow, the director of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services; and Todd Lyons, the acting director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, testifying on Tuesday.

item.title: F.D.A. Refuses to Review Moderna Flu Vaccine
item.description: The vaccine maker’s shots involve the successful Covid vaccines’ RNA technology. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has broadly rejected it, canceling millions of dollars in research projects.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett and Rebecca Robbins

media:content.media:description: Moderna is a pioneer in using mRNA technology, first with the Covid vaccine. Its flu shot was being developed for people 50 and older.

item.title: Song of the Week: Is This Zach Bryan’s Redemption Era?
item.description: On this edition of the “Popcast” Song of the Week, our critic Jon Caramanica dives into Zach Bryan’s “Appetite,” a redemptive and contemplative track about “the horrors that you visited upon yourself.”

item.title: Britney Spears Sells Her Song Catalog
item.description: The pop hitmaker, who hasn’t released a new album in 10 years, sold the rights to her music to Primary Wave.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario

media:content.media:description: Britney Spears has sold tens of millions of albums and scored five No. 1 hits on Billboard’s Hot 100 singles chart.

item.title: Surveillance Video Shows Masked Person at Guthrie’s Doorstep
item.description: Investigators detained a person for questioning in the disappearance of Nancy Guthrie after the authorities released new evidence of a masked suspect at her doorstep on the night she vanished.
item.dc:creator: Jackeline Luna

item.title: Ford Says Electric Vehicle Losses Will Continue for 3 More Years
item.description: Ford Motor reported a big loss for 2025 because of its troubled electric vehicle division, which it has significantly scaled back.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette

media:content.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: An F-150 Lightning electric pickup truck, which the company stopped producing last year, after federal tax credits for electric vehicles ended.

item.title: A.I. May Put Progressives to the Test
item.description: The left needs a sharper A.I. politics.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; source photographs by Cavan Images and feedough/Getty Images

item.title: Peter Attia’s Ties to Epstein Spark a Backlash From Doctors
item.description: What started as a rebuke of Dr. Attia has become a discussion about his credentials, longevity medicine and whom patients should trust.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor

item.title: Read the Fulton County search warrant affidavit
item.description: The document includes numerous claims about ballots and elections that have been widely debunked. Witnesses’ names were redacted before the affidavit was unsealed.

item.title: A Timeline of Nancy Guthrie’s Disappearance
item.description: A look at the major developments in the case.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:description: The authorities in Pima County, Ariz., have repeatedly closed and reopened the crime scene at Nancy Guthrie’s house near Tucson since she was reported missing on Feb. 1.

item.title: Mexican Cartel’s Seized Ammunition Is Traced to U.S. Army Plant
item.description: About 137,000 .50-caliber rounds have been seized since 2012, and of those, 47 percent came from a plant in Kansas City, Mo., Mexico’s defense secretary said.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega

media:content.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A police officer in Villa Unión, Mexico, with a .50-caliber cartridge. Mexico’s defense secretary said that about 137,000 .50-caliber rounds had been seized since 2012.

item.title: Nancy Guthrie Live Updates: A Suspect Is Being Questioned After a Traffic Stop
item.description: The development came several hours after investigators released chilling video showing a masked figure on Ms. Guthrie’s front porch the morning of her disappearance.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
